@Cheese_Police wrote:

jQuery is excellent, I haven’t used it too much but from examples and sample code I’ve seen, it definitely allows for some (mostly) clean and effective code.

On a side note, avoid document.write like the plague, use DOM instead. A quick google turned up this.

Learn jQuery.

learn javascript first though…
[/quote]this. I was going to say it, but I’m not too keen on the usage of jQuery.

Which do you prefer? Or are you against all frameworks?[/quote]I don’t do much of any Javascript lately. Prototype is the only one I “took a tour” of. I’m not against any frameworks, honestly I feel that the jQuery examples I have seen make Javascript look a whole lot better.

item.title: Javascript
item.dc:creator: @Tom Tom
item.description:
@Tom wrote:

Tabbykiller, I think he wants to keep it the same for every other name but the ones he specifies. I’ve never actually done js before but I’ve just tested this on localhost and all seems to be working well.

<html>
<head>
<script type="text/javascript">
function show_prompt()
{
var name=prompt("Please enter your name","Name Here");
if (name=="nick") {
  document.write("Welcome Nick.");
} else if (name!=null && name!="") {
  document.write("Hello " + name + "! How are you today?");
   }
}
</script>
</head>
<body>
<input type="button" onclick="show_prompt()" value="Show prompt box" />
</body>
</html>

Probably a better way of doing it, but it works.

Read full topic
